issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The product is working as designed.
resolution.name: Not a Bug

fields.summary: Elastic IP address user quotas are being applied to multiple users.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Using an automated UI script, I was testing EIP quotas and the script failed because it was not allowed to allocate an IP address after releasing it.  I tried to manually reproduce and I was able to using the steps below.  I also created a shell script to reproduce the problem using the CLI.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a user (user1) with an Elastic IP address quota of 2
2. Create another user (user2) with an Elastic IP address quota of 4
3. login as user1 and allocate your total quota ip addresses (do not release the addresses)
4. Logout as user1
5. Login as user2 and allocate your total quota IP addresses
6. Still logged in as user2, release an IP address and allocate again
(You may need to do this last step multiple times)

Expected result: You will not be able to allocate another IP address after you release it.

It appears as though the system might be using IP addresses from other users to calculate the quota.
fields.summary: Unable to allocate an IP address after releasing one using user quotas.

comments.body: [~ccassler], how long are you waiting before releasing one address and allocating another when you see this issue?
[~ccassler] Need more info as per [~sjones] question
[~sjones]: Try releasing more than one address and then allocate one additional address.  I was able to reproduce pretty quickly using that method.

[~ccassler], here's how I am testing this, let me know if I should be using a different approach:

{code}
#
# euare-accountcreate -a address-quota
address-quota	471801056734
#
#
# euare-usercreate --as-account address-quota -u user1
#
#
# euare-usercreate --as-account address-quota -u user2
#
#
# euare-useruploadpolicy --as-account address-quota -u user1 -p ec2 -o '{
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Action": [
        "ec2:*"
      ],
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Resource": "*"
    }
  ]
}'
#
#
# euare-useruploadpolicy --as-account address-quota -u user2 -p ec2 -o '{
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Action": [
        "ec2:*"
      ],
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Resource": "*"
    }
  ]
}'
#
#
# euare-useruploadpolicy --as-account address-quota -u user1 -p ec2-quota -o '{
  "Statement":[{
    "Effect":"Limit",
    "Action":"ec2:AllocateAddress",
    "Resource":"*",
    "Condition":{
      "NumericLessThanEquals":{
        "ec2:quota-addressnumber":"2"
      }
    }
  }]
}'
#
#
# euare-useruploadpolicy --as-account address-quota -u user2 -p ec2-quota -o '{
  "Statement":[{
    "Effect":"Limit",
    "Action":"ec2:AllocateAddress",
    "Resource":"*",
    "Condition":{
      "NumericLessThanEquals":{
        "ec2:quota-addressnumber":"2"
      }
    }
  }]
}'
# 
# 
# euare-useraddkey --as-account address-quota -u user1
AKICNDS3XCCG7PROR49I
pjD...
#
#
# euare-useraddkey --as-account address-quota -u user2
AKIQLIRVHTIR2OSFECX6
fHo...
# 
# 
# euca-allocate-address -I AKICNDS3XCCG7PROR49I -S pjD... # user1
ADDRESS	10.116.150.231	vpc	eipalloc-392804e9
# 
# 
# euca-allocate-address -I AKICNDS3XCCG7PROR49I -S pjD... # user1
ADDRESS	10.116.150.127	vpc	eipalloc-907590a9
# 
# 
# euca-allocate-address -I AKICNDS3XCCG7PROR49I -S pjD... # user1
euca-allocate-address: error (InternalFailure): Quota exceeded while trying to create: address by user: arn:aws:euare::471801056734:user/user1
# 
# 
# euca-allocate-address -I AKIQLIRVHTIR2OSFECX6 -S fHo... # user2
ADDRESS	10.116.150.55	vpc	eipalloc-5f63f0a2
# 
# 
# euca-allocate-address -I AKIQLIRVHTIR2OSFECX6 -S fHo... # user2
ADDRESS	10.116.150.19	vpc	eipalloc-af098409
# 
# 
# euca-allocate-address -I AKIQLIRVHTIR2OSFECX6 -S fHo... # user2
euca-allocate-address: error (InternalFailure): Quota exceeded while trying to create: address by user: arn:aws:euare::471801056734:user/user2
# 
# 
# euca-release-address -I AKIQLIRVHTIR2OSFECX6 -S fHo... 10.116.150.55 # user2
ADDRESS	10.116.150.55	
# 
# 
# euca-release-address -I AKIQLIRVHTIR2OSFECX6 -S fHo... 10.116.150.19 # user2
ADDRESS	10.116.150.19

ADDRESS	10.116.150.75	vpc	eipalloc-6ce3ebd4

ADDRESS	10.116.150.179	vpc	eipalloc-5422257a

ADDRESS	10.116.150.75

ADDRESS	10.116.150.179

ADDRESS	10.116.150.107	vpc	eipalloc-de0493e7

ADDRESS	10.116.150.7	vpc	eipalloc-b8c180bc

euca-allocate-address: error (InternalFailure): Quota exceeded while trying to create: address by user: arn:aws:euare::471801056734:user/user2

[~sjones]:  I'm able to reproduce this now in my environment consistently:  Here's how I did it using the CLI.  In this scenario, I had basically the same setup as you both users had a quota of 2 IP addresses.  When I release BOTH addresses from the second user and then try to allocate 2 new addresses, the issue happens.
{code}
[root@g-26-05 ~]# . ./testuser1/eucarc

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-describe-addresses

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-allocate-address
ADDRESS 10.111.74.165   standard

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-allocate-address
ADDRESS 10.111.74.188   standard

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-allocate-address
euca-allocate-address: error (InternalFailure): Quota exceeded while trying to create: address by user: arn:aws:euare::783999238694:user/testuser1

[root@g-26-05 ~]# . ./testuser2/eucarc

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-describe-addresses
ADDRESS 10.111.74.165       standard
ADDRESS 10.111.74.188       standard

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-allocate-address
ADDRESS 10.111.74.153   standard

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-allocate-address
ADDRESS 10.111.74.185   standard

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-describe-addresses
ADDRESS 10.111.74.153       standard
ADDRESS 10.111.74.165       standard
ADDRESS 10.111.74.185       standard
ADDRESS 10.111.74.188       standard

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-release-address `euca-describe-addresses | tail -1 | awk '{ print $2 }'`
ADDRESS 10.111.74.188

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-release-address `euca-describe-addresses | tail -1 | awk '{ print $2 }'`
ADDRESS 10.111.74.185

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-allocate-address
ADDRESS 10.111.74.196   standard

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-allocate-address
euca-allocate-address: error (InternalFailure): Quota exceeded while trying to create: address by user: arn:aws:euare::783999238694:user/testuser2

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-describe-addresses
ADDRESS 10.111.74.153       standard
ADDRESS 10.111.74.165       standard
ADDRESS 10.111.74.196       standard

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-allocate-address
euca-allocate-address: error (InternalFailure): Quota exceeded while trying to create: address by user: arn:aws:euare::783999238694:user/testuser2

[root@g-26-05 ~]# euca-describe-addresses
ADDRESS	10.111.74.153		standard
ADDRESS	10.111.74.165		standard
ADDRESS	10.111.74.196		standard
{code}

[~sjones]:  Here are the logs during the second user allocate failure as well.  In case there is anything unusual:
{code}

[~ccassler], I'm not following. Each users quota is 2 addresses so it is expected that when a user has 2 addresses they cannot allocate any more.

I thought that a user's quota was based on random IP addresses not specific.  So when I was deleting addresses, I was actually deleting addresses that were assigned to another user so it wasn't effecting the user quota I was logged in as.
